newsitem.title: USA: NHL-DALLAS STARS GIVE COACH HITCHCOCK CONTRACT EXTENSION.
newsitem.headline: NHL-DALLAS STARS GIVE COACH HITCHCOCK CONTRACT EXTENSION.

text.p: Dallas Stars head coach Ken Hitchcock, who took a last place team and guided it to the Central Division title this season, was given a contract extension on Monday through the 1998-99 season.
The 45-year-old Hitchcock, originally under contract through the 1997-98 campaign, was rewarded despite his team's ouster in the first round of the NHL Stanley Cup playoffs.
In his first full season as Dallas head coach, Hitchcock oversaw one of the most dramatic turnarounds in National Hockey League history.

After finishing the 1995-96 season last in the Central Division with a 26-42-14 record, Dallas posted the second best record in the league at 48-26-8 for 104 points -- franchise records for both victories and points, including the team's years as the Minnesota North Stars.
Despite the whopping 38-point improvement in the standings, however, the Stars were upset by the Edmonton Oilers in seven games in a first-round playoff series.
Hitchcock, who was promoted to his current job on January 8, 1996, is one of three finalists for the Jack Adams Award -- the NHL's version of Coach of the Year.
The Stars also gave contract extensions to assistant coaches Doug Jarvis and Rick Wilson through the 1998-99 season.
